Answer: You can achieve this by using a @OneToMany mapping with a cascade type of ALL, orphanRemoval set to true. Then, in your entity class A, you can use a method to limit the size of the collection.

<<<code>>>:

```java
@Entity
public class A {
    // fields
    @OneToMany(cascade = CascadeType.ALL, orphanRemoval = true)
    @OrderBy("id ASC")
    private List<B> b = new ArrayList<>();

    public void addB(B b) {
        if (this.b.size() >= 5) {
            this.b.remove(0);
        }
        this.b.add(b);
    }
}
```

In this code, the addB method checks if the size of the list 'b' is greater than or equal to 5. If it is, it removes the oldest entry (the one at index 0). Then it adds the new entry to the end of the list.

This way, you ensure that the size of the list 'b' never exceeds 5, and the oldest entry is removed when a new one is added.

Please note that you need to call addB method instead of directly adding to the list 'b' to ensure the size limit is maintained.

This solution is clean and does not require a separate job to remove the older entries.
